page.title: 02LOCAL HISTORY
page.content: BLOCK 6- IN THIS SMALL AREA THERE ARE TWO SITES OF LOCAL HISTORICAL INTEREST. THE FIRST IS A MOUND CALLED RISINGHOE CASTLE WHICH IS ASSUMED TO HAVE BEEN A 'LOOK-OUT'MOUND DATING BACK TO THE 10TH CENTURY.LEGEND ALLEGES THAT THE BODIES OF SOLDIERS KILLED IN THE BATTLE OF GOLDINGTON BRIDGE (917) WERE BURIED THERE. THE SECOND IS A WATER-MILL CALLED CASTLE MILL.ALTHOUGH THIS IS A VICTORIAN BUILDING IT IS BELIEVED TO STAND ON OR VERY CLOSE TO THE MILL MENTIONED IN THE ORIGINAL DOMESDAY BOOK.THE WATER MILL IS NOT IN USE BUT THE BUILDING APPEARS TO BE USED FOR STORAGE.ON THE N.E.SIDE OF THE MOUND IS A LARGE VICTORIAN HOUSE WHICH HAS BELONGED TO THE ROGERS FAMILY SINCE THE LAST CENTURY.ON THE W.SIDE OF THE MOUND ARE VICTORIAN COTTAGES.
